articles.title: Exploring JS: JavaScript Books for Programmers
articles.description: You’ll know Dr. Axel from his fantastic blog posts over the years, or his once tenure as JavaScript Weekly’s editor, but he also has an impressive array of no-nonsense books that you can mostly read for free online, including the newly updated Exploring JavaScript (ES2024 Edition), Deep JavaScript, and Tackling TypeScript.
articles.author: Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

articles.title: Node.js v22.5.0 (Current) Released
articles.description: A notable release for two reasons: first, the WebSocket feature in node:http is now exposed, but second, Node is embedding SQLite and now offers direct access to it via node:sqlite.
articles.author: Antoine du Hamel

articles.title: ▶  The Talks from dotJS 2024
articles.description: dotJS 2024 took place in Paris a few months ago, and now all the talks are available on YouTube. Highlights include Lea Verou talking about the parallels between API and UI design, David Flanagan on advancements in WebAssembly, and Minko Gechev on convergence of features in modern frameworks The talks are all short, so the takeaways are quick to get.
articles.author: YouTube

articles.title: How to Make Complex Chrome Extensions
articles.description: Spinning up a quick, simple browser extension isn’t that big of a deal nowadays, especially with tools like Extension to kick off a project. Larger extensions are a different story, so it’s neat to learn from the experiences of a team that’s built one.
articles.author: Nina Torgunakova

articles.title: A TypeScripter's Take on Zig
articles.description: Rust might be the cool systems language on the block right now, but Zig has a lot going for it too (Bun, notably, is implemented in it.) A good primer from a TypeScript perspective.
articles.author: Dan Vanderkam

articles.title: How Fast is JavaScript? Simulating 20 Million Particles
articles.description: “The challenge: simulate 1,000,000 particles in plain JavaScript at 60 FPS on a phone using only the CPU. Let’s go.” The sort of fun, detailed experimentation I’ll always support.
articles.author: David Gerrells

articles.title: A Guide to Reading and Writing Node.js Streams
articles.description: Matteo reminds us of the benefits of using Node’s powerful streaming data features, where they make sense, and how to handle back-pressure and error management.
articles.author: Matteo Collina

articles.title: What React Devs Need to Know About React Native
articles.description: While React and React Native share many similarities, they’re different under the hood. Here’s some of what you need to know to make the transition.
articles.author: Kadi Kraman (Expo)

articles.title: Poku 2.0: A Cross-Platform Test Runner for JS
articles.description: Poku’s philosophy is to ‘bring the JavaScript essence back to testing.’ It runs the same way across Node, Bun and Deno, and auto-detects ESM, CommonJS and TypeScript.
articles.author: Weslley Araújo

articles.title: InfiniteGrid 4.12: Arrange Card Elements Infinitely in a Grid Layout
articles.description: A mature and established way to create grids formed of card elements of varying sizes. Happy on both desktop and mobile and has integrations for React, Vue, Angular, Svelte, and others. GitHub repo.
articles.author: NAVER

articles.title: 🤖 Micro Agent: An AI Agent That Writes Code for You
articles.description: A Node.js-based tool that takes the approach of writing a test case first and then iterates upon a solution until the tests pass.
articles.author: Builder․io

articles.title: Hyphenopoly 6.0: A Polyfill for Client-Side Hyphenation
articles.description: Hyphenates text if the user agent or language doesn't support CSS hyphenation (a feature that’s part of Baseline but with widely varying support). An interesting use of WebAssembly.
articles.author: Mathias Nater

articles.title: simplex-noise.js: A Fast Simplex Noise Implementation
articles.description: Small, self contained, and fast, and you can use it in cool demos like this or for applying convincing grain/noise to images or other data, say.
articles.author: Jonas Wagner

articles.title: Maska 3.0: Zero-Dependency Input Mask Library
articles.description: Several demos on the homepage. Lightweight and framework independent but offers Vue 2/3, Alpine.js and Svelte integrations. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Form․io

articles.description: The annual JS1024 JavaScript golfing competition is currently running with submissions due tomorrow. You have to build a JavaScript demo in just 1KB and there are lots of links to tools and tutorials there to help.
The first beta of TypeScript 5.6 is expected next week – here's the TypeScript 5.6 iteration plan if you want to get ahead on the features and schedule.
ESLint v9.7.0 – Supports ES2025 duplicate capturing groups in regexes. Duy Ng also shares some tips on migrating to ESLint 9+.
Boa 0.19 – A JS engine written in Rust for embedding in other projects.
Meteor 3.0 – Full-stack framework for real-time apps.
jQuery 4.0 Beta 2, htmx 2.0.1, swc 1.7

articles.title: CSS Selectors
articles.description: A thorough, complete guide/reference covering all of the various methods we have to select elements in CSS (such as pseudo-selectors, nested selectors, attribute selectors, etc) and how to use them for applying styles.
articles.author: Geoff Graham

articles.title: Seamless SVG Copy-Paste on the Web
articles.description: Support has been added to Chromium browsers for SVG files in the Async Clipboard API. This means copying and pasting SVG data across any app that wants to use SVG, whether it’s native or web, becomes possible.
articles.author: Taylore Givens and Patrick Brosset

articles.title: @property: Next-Gen CSS Variables Now with Universal Browser Support
articles.description: The @property rule, part of the CSS Houdini umbrella of APIs, is now fully supported across all modern browsers.
articles.author: Una Kravets

articles.title: Private Browsing 2.0 in Safari
articles.description: First included as a feature in Safari almost twenty years ago, ‘Private Browsing’ has been getting a big revamp over the past year. The WebKit team explains what changes and enhancements have occurred and the mitigations to prevent breaking existing sites.
articles.author: The WebKit Team

articles.title: An Update on Invokers: Invoker Commands in HTML
articles.description: An overview of this experimental syntax which will allow devs to assign behavior to elements in a declarative and accessible way.
articles.author: Brecht De Ruyte

articles.title: ▶  Dialog Dilemmas and Modal Mischief: A Deep Dive into Popovers
articles.description: A talk from the All Day Hey! conference on dialogs, including the new popover attribute, “modality” and using the top layer.
articles.author: Hidde de Vries

articles.title: ▶  Utility First CSS Isn’t Inline Styles
articles.description: A 52-minute talk on the comparison often made between utility first options versus inline styling. Related slides here.
articles.author: Sarah Dayan

articles.title: Embracing Functional CSS: Have We Moved On?
articles.description: A look at the positives of utility-first CSS, and why we’ve become accustomed to introducing it to our workflows.
articles.author: Oliver Creswell

articles.title: JPEG History: Compressing It Down, Keeping the Essence
articles.description: How the JPEG file — and the lossy compression it allowed and encouraged — became the dominant way we shared digital photos on the internet.
articles.author: Ernie Smith

articles.title: CSS Grid Generator
articles.description: A handy browser-based tool that can create custom CSS grid layouts. The generator allows you to specify the number of columns, rows, and gutter size.
articles.author: Kristjan Retter

articles.title: Eruda 3.1: A Console for Mobile Browsers
articles.description: If you’re in a situation where you have no access to DevTools, you can add Eruda to your page and it provides a sort of virtual devtools you can use from any browser, including on mobile.
articles.author: LiriLiri

articles.title: Linefont: A Typeface for Rendering Line Chart Data
articles.description: A one-of-a-kind font that’s part of Google Fonts that technically falls under the “display” fonts category. This interactive demo lets you adjust the weight, width, and size to get an idea of what’s possible.
articles.author: Dmitry Ivanov

articles.title: Hyphenopoly 6.0: A Polyfill for Client-Side Hyphenation
articles.description: Hyphenates text if the user agent does not support CSS hyphenation (a feature that’s part of Baseline but with widely varying support) or not for the language present. An interesting use of WebAssembly too.
articles.author: Mathias Nater

articles.title: unplugin-turbo-console: Improve the Developer Experience of console.log()
articles.description: Part of UnJS’s Unplugin ecosystem, this enhancement to console.log() allows you to print the file name, line number, variable name, has highlighting for different file types, and features jump-to-source with one click.
articles.author: Unplugin
